div.h1: All Salem-Keizer Public Schools will stay closed for the remainder of the school year. For more information, please visit our Coronavirus Updates and Resources web page.

div.class: fusion-layout-column fusion_builder_column fusion_builder_column_1_1 fusion-builder-column-1 fusion-one-full fusion-column-first fusion-column-last 1_1

img.alt: Distance Learning For All Begins April 13, 2020

div.class: fusion-layout-column fusion_builder_column fusion_builder_column_1_1 fusion-builder-column-2 fusion-one-full fusion-column-first fusion-column-last 1_1

div.h2: Instructional Videos to Support Distance Learning

div.p: Please take the time to review our series of instructional videos below to help get you started with distance learning. We will continue to provide new ways to support you and your child throughout this process and help create as much normalcy as possible.

On April 13, 2020 we will begin learning like we never have before. On March 30, the Oregon Department of Education (ODE) announced the statewide change to “Distance Learning for All” in response to the Coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic, which has closed our schools since March 16.

As we adapt to Distance Learning, equitable outcomes for all students remains our focus, and we will continue to hold equity at the center of our work, while supporting the academic, mental and social-emotional needs of our students. Salem-Keizer Public Schools’ Distance Learning plan aligns with guidance from ODE and provides for synchronous and asynchronous learning as well as a commitment to providing access to educational materials through multiple modes, such as virtual classroom and printed learning packets.
One of the most important aspects of helping to make distance learning successful is staying connected. Without our families, distance learning would not be possible.

Each week teachers will share assignments and activities through Google Classroom (K-12) or Seesaw (K-5), and provide multiple opportunities for students to virtually collaborate and connect with their peers and teachers.

Help your child where possible, talk positively about distance learning and reach out to your teacher when you run into challenges. Communication is key to our success; but remember, everyone’s best is different and everyone’s best is okay. We must provide grace and understanding as we all learn how distance learning works best for us.

As the primary mode for distance learning will be held through online platforms, it’s important to keep internet safety in mind with your children. Please be sure to review our internet safety tips that are useful anytime your child has access to an internet-connected device.

div.class: fusion-panel fusion-toggle-no-divider panel-default fusion-faq-post fusion-faq-post-45727 distance-learning dl-faq
div.span: Where can I access support? I am feeling very overwhelmed with all of the changes due to the COVID-19 Pandemic.

a.div: Where can I access support? I am feeling very overwhelmed with all of the changes due to the COVID-19 Pandemic.

div.p: Please ask for help. We have a lot of information about community resources which can help with food, utilities, communication with landlords, mental health (anxiety included!) and many other needs. Please reach out to anyone in our school community to express your needs.
Please view our list of local crisis resources for families.
In addition, Marion County Health & Human Services has established a Warmline to help community members access resources to help them through the COVID-19 pandemic. Learn more.

div.class: fusion-panel fusion-toggle-no-divider panel-default fusion-faq-post fusion-faq-post-45725 distance-learning dl-faq
div.span: I can’t get my child logged on. Where can I go for help?

a.div: I can’t get my child logged on. Where can I go for help?

div.p: Your child’s teacher will be a good first resource. You can also reach out for technical support through our student help desk by calling 971-373-6114 or filling out the online form.

div.class: fusion-panel fusion-toggle-no-divider panel-default fusion-faq-post fusion-faq-post-45591 distance-learning dl-faq
div.span: How are in-district transfers being handled?

a.div: How are in-district transfers being handled?

div.p: The deadline to turn in IDT applications has been extended to Friday, April 17, 2020, due to school closures. Please review more information about the extension to learn how to submit your IDT application online.

div.class: fusion-panel fusion-toggle-no-divider panel-default fusion-faq-post fusion-faq-post-45589 distance-learning dl-faq
div.span: How can students access personal items left in school lockers?

a.div: How can students access personal items left in school lockers?

div.p: Now that we have further direction about the extension of the closure, we will follow up with a safe process that adheres to social distancing guidelines.

div.class: fusion-panel fusion-toggle-no-divider panel-default fusion-faq-post fusion-faq-post-45542 distance-learning dl-faq

div.p: To align with guidance issued by ODE, the SKPS Distance Learning Plan will be moving to a pass, no grade system in grades 6-12 for the remainder of the closure period.
As we evaluate this guidance, we will communicate additional details directly from your school, and high school seniors will receive individual guidance on next steps.

We will continue to honor distance learning for all of our students in grades K-5, and we will follow a plan to report on progress toward focused standards for Distance Learning. Distance learning begins on Monday, April 13, but please know we do not expect it to look like the school days we had only a handful of weeks ago.

div.class: fusion-panel fusion-toggle-no-divider panel-default fusion-faq-post fusion-faq-post-45534 distance-learning dl-faq
div.span: How can I provide additional learning opportunities for my child?

a.div: How can I provide additional learning opportunities for my child?

div.p: In additional to required Distance Learning, families can access our supplemental learning resources. These resources for supplemental learning are not intended to replace classroom instruction or district-adopted curriculum. No content will be graded and all of these activities are optional.

div.class: fusion-panel fusion-toggle-no-divider panel-default fusion-faq-post fusion-faq-post-45532 distance-learning dl-faq
div.span: Is there going to be a daily live classroom?

a.div: Is there going to be a daily live classroom?

div.p: At the elementary level, your child’s teacher will set up two times during the week for a live lesson. Don’t worry, if you can’t make it, it will be recorded for you later.
At the secondary level (middle & high school), students have two opportunities a week for live office hours with each of their teachers.

div.class: fusion-panel fusion-toggle-no-divider panel-default fusion-faq-post fusion-faq-post-45529 distance-learning dl-faq

div.p: Distance Learning is not optional. What is optional is when you choose to log-on and have your kids complete their work. This will look different for all families and that is okay.

div.class: fusion-panel fusion-toggle-no-divider panel-default fusion-faq-post fusion-faq-post-45527 distance-learning dl-faq
div.span: What will Distance Learning look like?

a.div: What will Distance Learning look like?

div.p: Distance Learning is a new concept for many of us and is unlike anything we have ever experienced before. This way of learning may look different for all students. You set up the learning time that fits your families’ needs.

Salem-Keizer Public Schools’ Distance Learning plan aligns with guidance from ODE and provides for synchronous and asynchronous learning as well as a commitment to providing access to educational materials through multiple modes, such as virtual classroom and printed learning packets. Distance Learning is teacher-led learning, unlike supplemental learning which is meant to supplement what a student is learning with their teacher, but it not required or monitored by their teacher.

p.strong: The state’s guidelines for distance learning include recommended maximum daily teacher-led instructional times:

li.span: Grade K–1: 45 minutes
Grades 2–3: 60 minutes
Grades 4–5: 90 minutes
Grades 6–12: 30 minutes per teacher (3 hours in a day)

p.span: In addition to the daily maximum teacher-led instructional minutes, ODE recommends that students participate in supplemental learning activities that are age and grade appropriate and that are student- or family-led. Your student’s teacher may send home suggested supplemental learning activities or you may reference the supplemental learning resources webpage

p.strong: ODE’s guidelines for student- or family-led supplemental learning activities include recommended daily times:

li.span: Grade K–1: 1 – 2 hours
Grades 2–3: 2 hours
Grades 4–5: 3 hours
Grades 6–12:1 – 2 hours

div.class: fusion-panel fusion-toggle-no-divider panel-default fusion-faq-post fusion-faq-post-45525 distance-learning dl-faq
div.span: What if I don’t have access to the internet to access online learning?

a.div: What if I don’t have access to the internet to access online learning?

div.p: We are currently making contact with those families identified as being without access so that we can create no-cost solutions. Please be sure to let your child’s teacher know if you are having trouble accessing materials due to internet access. Printed packets in language arts, math and social emotional learning are currently available for elementary students at all 36 meal locations. On April 20, packets for middle school students will also be available in language arts, science, math and social studies. High school students who need a printed packet should request these from their teacher.

div.class: fusion-panel fusion-toggle-no-divider panel-default fusion-faq-post fusion-faq-post-45523 distance-learning dl-faq
div.span: What happens if my student has trouble getting started next week?

a.div: What happens if my student has trouble getting started next week?

div.p: We want to do everything we can to help you hit the ground running. If you experience any difficultly getting started, please review our instructional learning videos. If you still need assistance, contact your child’s school by calling the main telephone line and someone will return your call as soon as possible.

div.class: fusion-panel fusion-toggle-no-divider panel-default fusion-faq-post fusion-faq-post-45521 distance-learning dl-faq
div.span: Where can I get a printed packet of learning materials?

a.div: Where can I get a printed packet of learning materials?

div.p: Printed packets in language arts, math and social emotional learning are currently available for elementary students at all 36 meal locations. On April 20, packets for middle school students will also be available and more curricular areas will be available the week of April 27. High school students you need a printed packet should request these from their teacher.

div.class: fusion-panel fusion-toggle-no-divider panel-default fusion-faq-post fusion-faq-post-45455 dl-faq
div.span: How does my middle or high school child access their learning?

a.div: How does my middle or high school child access their learning?

div.p: Students can access their learning through their student email account. It is suggested for all secondary students to regularly check their email, at least twice per day.

With the announcement of school buildings remaining closed for the remainder of the 2019-20 school year comes important guidance for high school students, particularly our nearly 3,000 high school seniors. There is no change to the number of credits required to graduate. We now consider March 13th as the final day of coursework just for students in the class of 2020, and we will issue a .5 credit as “Pass,” or “No Grade” for the work completed to this date. This guidance applies to students set to graduate in June of 2020. For those seniors who don’t have enough credits as of March 13, we will create individualized distance learning schedules to help you earn credits through the end of the school year to stay on track with the Class of 2020. In addition, Essential Skills and Personalized Learning Requirements are suspended.

li.b: Students will use their school Gmail account to access their learning. Students should check their email at least twice per day.

li.span: Students will continue all courses that they were enrolled in prior to the closure. The exception to this is “Student Aide,” “Peer Tutor” or other such courses that cannot be continued during distance learning.
All coursework will be posted in Google Classrooms by 8 a.m. each Monday.
Teachers will post weekly agendas for all work as the first assignment for the week.

Teachers will provide two live help sessions per week. Days/times will be communicated by the teacher in the weekly agenda each week. Teachers will still continue to provide help via email, Remind and/or phone.
Students will have a common lesson regarding agenda planners and how to organize their work during Week 1 (April 13).
For Middle School, at least English Language Arts and Math courses will be posted April 13. Other courses will launch on or before April 20. For High School, all courses will begin April 13.
All courses will be graded Pass/No Grade. This grading does not impact GPA. GPA will be calculated using Semester 1 final grades and will pick up again in the Fall of 20-21 school year.

Printed packets for Middle School in English Language arts and Math will be available at all meal sites starting April 20. Students should contact their High School teachers if they need a paper packet.
Students receiving special services will continue to receive support from teachers and staff.

hr.p: This guidance issued by ODE aligns with the SKPS Distance Learning Plan in that the district will be moving to a pass, no grade system in grades 6-12 for the remainder of the closure period.
As we evaluate this guidance, we will communicate additional details directly from your school, and high school seniors will receive individual guidance on next steps.

We will continue to honor distance learning for all of our students in grades K-5, and we will follow a plan to report on progress toward focused standards for Distance Learning. Distance learning begins on Monday, April 13, but please know we do not expect it to look like the school days we had only a handful of weeks ago.

li.span: Google Meet will be used for face-to-face instruction. Students will receive invitations or links from their classroom teacher to participate. These links and invitations will be shared in advance via Seesaw or Google Classroom.
During a Meet, students’ faces and names will be displayed on screen.

b.i: If they do not want to be seen by other students, please have them turn their camera off on their screen

li.span: . This is completed by clicking the video camera icon on the Meet screen.

To support students that cannot meet during a scheduled synchronous Meet session, teachers may record a Meet for distribution to students not in attendance.Again, if a student doesn’t want to be recorded for later viewing by other students, please turn off the camera on their device. This is completed by clicking the video camera icon on the Meet screen.

ul.li: To protect student privacy, videos that are recorded for targeted distribution will not be posted on a public webpage. These videos will be stored on a district-hosted site and a view-only link will be shared within Seesaw or Google Classroom or sent only to those families that are unable to participate in a synchronous event. These videos will be permanently deleted after 14 days.

Most teacher-initiated content will be delivered in an online learning format; however, we do have options for families that are unable to participate. For those families that are unable to participate in online learning, we will continue to provide an approximation of this learning via paper packet distribution at our grab and go meal locations.
Class assignments, activities and schedule will be posted each Monday by 8 a.m. in your child’s Seesaw or Google Classroom.

hr.p: Case managers, educators and other staff will be contacting families within the first couple of weeks of distance learning to determine what supports your student may need to ensure access to the general curriculum in Distance Learning.

Each case manager will be reviewing IEPs to consider how to best support each student given these extraordinary circumstances. In cases where we have determined it will be a significant challenge to provide services that we estimate will confer meaningful benefit, we will reach out to you for consultation and to consider amending the IEP to discuss the most essential skills we can work on, to the extent practical.

Our intention is to hold meetings for any initial evaluation and/or 3-year reevaluation for which the assessments are complete. If the assessments are not complete, then the evaluation may be put on hold until schools re-open and the student is available for evaluation. You may be contacted to reconvene the Evaluation Planning Team to review if previously determined assessments for which consent was provided are still necessary, or if other assessments may be pursued that are available in a virtual or distance format.
Read the full message from Student Services Director Eric Richards in regard to distance learning and IEPs.
